Welcome to Radiant Logic DevOps

This site provides resources for DevOps professionals to deploy the RadiantOne platform. Docker images and Kubernetes for orchestration allows for easily deploying the RadiantOne platform in the cloud.

Global sync guide

Introduction
The RadiantOne Global Sync module is an advanced set of tools for synchronization and identity management

Deployment The components required for synchronization are: Agents, Queues, and Sync Engine/processor. These components ensure guaranteed message delivery and recoverability in case some part of the process is temporarily down/offline.

Uploads If the target/destination needs populated with entries before starting synchronization, perform an initial upload. Uploads can be performed from the Main Control Panel or from a command line utility.

Connector Properties guide

Overview Connectors are used for synchronization in the RadiantOne Global Sync module and have three main functions: 1) Query data sources and collect changed entries, 2) Filter unneeded events, and 3) publish changed entries with the required information (requested attributes).

Configuring connector types and properties The process of configuring connector properties and the property definitions described throughout the rest of this section are applicable to all connector types.

LDAP connectors There are two types of LDAP connectors: Changelog and Persistent Search. These connector types are described in this chapter.

Active Directory Connectors There are three types of Active Directory connectors: USNChanged, DirSync and Hybrid. These connector types are described in this chapter.

Database Changelog (Triggers) Connector When a database object is configured as a publisher, triggers are installed on the object and document all changes to a log table.

Database Timestamp Connector For Oracle, SQL Server, MySQL, MariaDB, and Salesforce backends (using the RadiantOne JDBC driver), a timestamp-based change detection mechanism is available.

Global Identity Builder Guide

Introduction to Global Identity Builder Introduction to Global Identity Builder.

Global Identity Builder concepts This chapter introduces concepts applicable to the Global Identity Builder.

Create a Global Identity Builder project This chapter presents how to create a Global Identity Builder project.

Perform manual identity administration With every Global Identity Builder project, there is usually an element of manual intervention required after initial project creation.

Manage real-time persistent cache refresh Once a Global Identity Builder project is complete, the global profile is kept up to date with changes that happen in the identity sources using real-time persistent cache refresh.

Link existing groups to global profile identities Many client applications leverage LDAP directories for authentication and a policy information point. These applications rely on group memberships for enforcing authorization and personalization.

Integrate and configure a custom data source The custom data source example described in this section is Azure AD.

Adress group membership challenges Adress group membership challenges.

Extend the global profile view Extend the global profile view

AWS Cloud Installation Guide

Radiant One Configuration Radiant One Configuration.

children.value: This site provides resources for DevOps professionals to deploy the RadiantOne platform. Docker images and Kubernetes for orchestration allows for easily deploying the RadiantOne platform in the cloud.
The RadiantOne Global Sync module is an advanced set of tools for synchronization and identity management

The components required for synchronization are: Agents, Queues, and Sync Engine/processor. These components ensure guaranteed message delivery and recoverability in case some part of the process is temporarily down/offline.
If the target/destination needs populated with entries before starting synchronization, perform an initial upload. Uploads can be performed from the Main Control Panel or from a command line utility.

Connectors are used for synchronization in the RadiantOne Global Sync module and have three main functions: 1) Query data sources and collect changed entries, 2) Filter unneeded events, and 3) publish changed entries with the required information (requested attributes).
The process of configuring connector properties and the property definitions described throughout the rest of this section are applicable to all connector types.
There are two types of LDAP connectors: Changelog and Persistent Search. These connector types are described in this chapter.
There are three types of Active Directory connectors: USNChanged, DirSync and Hybrid. These connector types are described in this chapter.
When a database object is configured as a publisher, triggers are installed on the object and document all changes to a log table.
For Oracle, SQL Server, MySQL, MariaDB, and Salesforce backends (using the RadiantOne JDBC driver), a timestamp-based change detection mechanism is available.
This chapter introduces concepts applicable to the Global Identity Builder.
Create a Global Identity Builder project
This chapter presents how to create a Global Identity Builder project.
With every Global Identity Builder project, there is usually an element of manual intervention required after initial project creation.
Once a Global Identity Builder project is complete, the global profile is kept up to date with changes that happen in the identity sources using real-time persistent cache refresh.
Link existing groups to global profile identities
Many client applications leverage LDAP directories for authentication and a policy information point. These applications rely on group memberships for enforcing authorization and personalization.
Integrate and configure a custom data source
The custom data source example described in this section is Azure AD.
